title: Tally rises for Brisbane's unprecedented big ticket sales
text:
Two of the largest commercial property deals in Brisbane this year have transacted within just a few days of each other as the improving office market lures investors deprived of assets elsewhere across the country.

The Brisbane market has had an unprecedented run of big ticket property sales of more than $200 million this year, led by the sale of 400 George Street to Cromwell for $524.75 million. Investors have been attracted to the city's falling vacancy rate, solid net absorption, and a $15 billion infrastructure boom which is currently underway.

QIC is selling the final big office asset in its property fund, the Q&A Centre in Brisbane. Supplied

Last week fund manager AsheMorgan completed its acquisition of The Complex, a cluster of three buildings in the Brisbane CBD, for $425 million on a yield of 6.4 per cent – the second largest deal of the year.

The asset, which was part of the $1.8 billion Investa office portfolio that Canada's Oxford Properties earmarked for divestment at the beginning of the year, sold through Cushman & Wakefield's Josh Cullen and Mark Hansen.

This week Queensland Investment Corporation's real estate arm sold its mixed-use commercial asset, Q &A Centre, to Taiwanese-backed developer Shayher Group in the third biggest transaction of 2019, at $395 million, on a yield of 6.25 per cent.
description: Taiwanese-backed Shayher Group has bought the Q&A Centre in Brisbane's CBD on a yield of 6.25 per cent.
